form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Ricketts (for himself, Mr. Risch, Mrs. Capito, Mr. Schmitt, Mr. Crapo, Ms. Lummis, Mrs. Fischer, Mr. Barrasso, Mr. Scott of Florida, and Ms. Slotkin) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry

form.official-title: To direct the Secretary of Agriculture to publish, on an annual basis, an assessment of United States dependency on critical agricultural products or inputs from the People’s Republic of China, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Securing American Agriculture Act.

section.header: Critical agricultural products or inputs assessment

subsection.text: On an annual basis, the Secretary of Agriculture (referred to in this section as the Secretary) shall submit to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate and the Committee on Agriculture of the House of Representatives an assessment of the dependency of the United States on critical agricultural products or inputs that could be exploited in the event the People’s Republic of China weaponizes any such dependency.

paragraph.text: address, with respect to the critical inputs described in subsection (c)—

subparagraph.text: the current domestic production capacity of each critical input; and
the current and potential bottlenecks in the supply chain for each critical input that could be exploited by the People’s Republic of China; and

paragraph.text: contain recommendations of the Secretary, in consultation with the United States Trade Representative, the Secretary of Commerce, and the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, to reduce the dependency of the United States on the People’s Republic of China to supply critical agricultural products or inputs, including recommendations—

subparagraph.text: to mitigate potential threats posed by the People’s Republic of China to the supply chains of each critical input described in subsection (c); and
for legislative and regulatory actions to reduce barriers to onshore or nearshore production of each such critical input.

subsection.text: The critical inputs referred to in subsection (b) include all farm management, agronomic, and field-applied production inputs, including each of the following:

paragraph.text: Feed, including its components, such as vitamins, amino acids, and minerals.
Any other critical agricultural inputs, as determined by the Secretary.

subsection.header: Collection, distribution, and protection of information

paragraph.text: In conducting an assessment under subsection (a), the Secretary shall not require any private entity to provide information to the Secretary.

In the case of information provided to the Secretary to conduct an assessment under subsection (a), the Secretary, any other officer or employee of the Department of Agriculture or agency thereof, or any other person shall not—

subparagraph.text: use that information for a purpose other than the development or reporting of aggregate data in a manner such that the identity of the person that supplied the information is not—

clause.text: material to the intended uses of the information; or

subparagraph.text: disclose that information to the public, unless the information has been transformed into a statistical or aggregate form that does not allow the identification of the person that supplied particular information.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall ensure that the assessments under subsection (a) do not include any information that is a trade secret or confidential information subject to—

subparagraph.text: section 552(b)(4) of title 5, United States Code; or
section 1905 of title 18, United States Code.

paragraph.text: Information provided to the Secretary as part of an assessment conducted under subsection (a) shall not be used by the Secretary for any purpose other than to carry out that subsection.
